slides.title: The Golden Age
slides.content:
# Islamic Science üïå

While Europe was in "Dark Ages", science flourished in the Middle East (8th-13th Century).
- Baghdad (House of Wisdom).
- Translated Greek texts to Arabic, saving them.

slides.title: Algorithm and Algebra
slides.content:
# Al-Khwarizmi ‚ûó

Persian mathematician.
- Wrote "Al-Jabr" (Algebra).
- His name is root of "Algorithm".
- Introducted Hindu-Arabic numerals (0-9) to West.

slides.title: Ibn Sina (Avicenna)
slides.content:
# The Canon of Medicine üìñ

- Wrote definitive medical encyclopedia used in Europe until 1650.
- Described quarantine, contagion, and testing drugs.

slides.title: Optics
slides.content:
# Ibn al-Haytham üëÅÔ∏è

Father of modern optics.
- Proved light travels in straight lines into the eye (Intromission) rather than eye shooting beams (Emission).
- Invented Camera Obscura.

slides.title: Medieval Europe
slides.content:
# Scholasticism ‚úùÔ∏è

University system began (Oxford, Paris).
- Using reason to understand God.
- Thomas Aquinas: Reconciling Aristotle's logic with Christian faith.

slides.title: Math Quiz
slides.quizQuestion: Where does the word 'Algebra' come from?

slides.title: Medieval Technology
slides.content:
# Inventions ‚öôÔ∏è

- **Heavy Plough**: Revolutionized farming in North.
- **Watermills/Windmills**: Mechanical power.
- **Mechanical Clock**: Controlled time (and life).

slides.title: Alchemy Continues
slides.content:
# Quest for Stone üíé

Philosopher's Stone.
- Jabir ibn Hayyan (Geber): Father of chemistry. Distilled alcohol and sulfur.
- Roger Bacon: English friar/alchemist, emphasized experimentation.

slides.title: Hospitals
slides.content:
# Care Centers üè•

- First general hospitals built in Islamic world (Bimaristans).
- Separated patients by disease.
- Paid staff and pharmacies.

slides.title: Astronomy
slides.content:
# The Stars üåü

- Improved Astrolabes (Navigation/Time).
- Named many stars (Aldebaran, Betelgeuse, Rigel - all Arabic names).
- Critiqued Ptolemy, setting stage for Copernicus.

slides.title: Ockham's Razor
slides.content:
# Simplicity ü™í

William of Ockham.
- "Entities should not be multiplied beyond necessity."
- The simplest explanation is usually the correct one.
- Key scientific principle.

slides.title: Brief Renaissance
slides.content:
# Carolingian üëë

Charlemagne (800 AD) promoted literacy and schools.
- Alcuin of York.
- Standardized writing (Carolingian minuscule).

slides.title: The Black Death
slides.content:
# Plague üêÄ

1347. Killing 30-60% of Europe.
- Slowed science momentarily.
- But shook trust in ancient authorities (Galen) who couldn't cure it.
- Led to social changes allowing Renaissance.

slides.quizQuestion: Ockham's Razor suggests that when facing two explanations, you should choose the:

slides.title: Printing Press
slides.content:
# Information Age üñ®Ô∏è

Gutenberg (1440).
- Not strictly science, but enabled it.
- Books became cheap.
- Ideas (and diagrams) could spread accurately and fast.

slides.title: Leonardo da Vinci
slides.content:
# Polymath üé®

Bridge to Renaissance.
- Artist, Engineer, Anatomist.
- Designed flying machines, tanks.
- Dissected bodies in secret (drawings were centuries ahead).

slides.title: Navigation
slides.content:
# Exploration ‚õµ

- Magnetic Compass adopted.
- Lateen Sail (Triangular) allowed sailing against wind.
- Age of Discovery followed.

slides.title: Medieval Summary
slides.content:
# Recap üìù

- Not strictly "Dark".
- **Islamic Golden Age** preserved and advanced knowledge.
- **Universities** were born.
- **Experimentation** began to challenge Authority.
